for_sales.sales_text:
Built Arnside 1902, a well known gaff-rigged yacht on Nobby/Morcambe bay prawner lines. 29ft LOA. Located in Bangor, N Wales. With all Sails and gear:

-Sails. Main in good condition; 2-3 Stays VG-G; Roller reefing Jib Excellent; and few misc older sails inc. Topsail.

-Mast & Rigging. Many wooden blocks replaced new by a previous owner. Original wooden mast, generally good, requires some repair by pulley for topsail.

-Engine. Betamarine BD722. New in 2007. Turns over with compression. Removed from boat.

Sails and rigging in dry storage, mast and engine stored offsite.

Hull:   Requires significant work now.   Numerous frames (mainly amidships) require repaired/replaced.

Hoodends, P/S, 5-6 up from garboard require repair. Stem good condition. There are also some smaller repairs to complete; P/S toe rail; P/S partial uppermost rubbing strake(?) by gunwale; P/S towing/trawling/mooring block. The majority of the concrete ballast has been removed and the keelson lifted out. A recent inspection by a shipwright detailed the following:

Planking:

Overall the planking seems in reasonable condition. Iron fastening corrosion, unknown condition but planks coming loose at hood ends and around the turn of the bilge. Will most likely require removal of planking and refastening to frames.

Rot around forward ends of port side, possibly extending into the stem. Significant rot around stern post hood ends hidden behind repairs, likely to extend into stern post.

Extensive rot around counter stern fashion pieces and throughout the counter stern. Repairs made to the area require alterations to return them to original condition.

Deck:

Deck and rubbing strakes in questionable condition due to delamination of glass sheath and plywood. Very likely requiring complete removal of cabin, toe rails and deck to expose condition of structure and to allow access to internal hull repairs.

Internal hull structure:

Extensive rot and partial delamination of frames, particularly around the bilge where fresh water has been sat. Further concrete to be removed to allow access to structure. Actual condition of keel timber can only assessed after removing some planks and concrete ballast.

This is a well known boat with lots of history. During her 119 years she has championed in numerous races and has been much admired locally and further afield. She is well documented in various publications. I shall upload some scans in a future post.

I've been working on this boat during weekends for the past few months with some help from friends. Due to my physical health I've decided to pass the project on.

Please get in touch using "contact the owner" button. Happy to have a chat on the phone or in person, arrange a viewing or provide more photos.   She is offered free to a suitably qualified new custodian.

boat.full_description:
‘Ploughboy’ was built for John Jackson of North Scales as a replacement for ‘Cock of the North’, which had been wrecked on her maiden voyage from Arnside in December 1900. ‘Ploughboy’ is thought to have had portable side decks, which could be removed to enable her to qualify as an open boat improving her racing handicap.

In the 1920s she may have been used for fishing. Her sail number is FD44 (Fleetwood). In the 1930s she took part in the Fleetwood – Isle of Man Race. Bought in 1965 by John Gill, a housemaster at Rossall School near Fleetwood, the boat was used to teach sailing to boys at the school.

History

1900: John Jackson of North Scales, Walney Island who was a farmer, ferryman or both ordered ‘Cock of the North’ from Crossfield Brothers for £70. Having left Arnside in calm weather, ‘Cock of the North’ was wrecked in a gale on her maiden voyage. She was crewed by John Jackson and his three sons and was lost when entering the Walney Channel off Piel Island with tide and wind against her. All her crew survive unharmed. 1901: Local boatmen take a collection for a replacement boat. A poem is written about the ‘Cock of the North’ which is said to have been recited in the local theatre to raise money. 1902: John Jackson orders ‘Ploughboy’ as a replacement yacht. As part of the contract Crossfields had to deliver the boat to Walney Island. 1907: Recorded as taking part in both Roa Island and First Barrow Yacht Club Regattas, owned by J.Jackson. In this year she won the Vickerstown and North Scale Gayner Cup, which was named after Sir George Gayner MP by winning it three times. (1903, 1905, 1907)

Mr Jimmy Jackson remembered crewing with his father in 'Plougboy', along with his elder brother Harry. Jimmy's job was to shift the ballast up to the weather side when racing. When one considers that the ballast consisted of 56lb weights one can imagine that hard work was the order of the day when beating to windward. On occasions 'Ploughboy' was skippered by a professional seaman from St Annes, and a local man by the name of Fred Woods was also known to have acted as helmsman during racing. 1914-5: Sold to "Dutch Jack" Verscholye, (the skipper of the Workington dredger), then later she was sold to Mr Ford of Haverigg.

Returning to Barrow in the early 1920s she was purchased by Mr Thompson who modified her keel with the addition of extra weights bolted on each side. 1920s: Recorded as taking part in Wardleys Regatta on River Wyre near Fleetwood, owned by J.Thompson of Ramsden Dock Road, Barrow. 1922: Recorded as taking part in the half decked fishing boat race at Morecambe Regatta, owned T.Thompson of Morecambe, suggesting use as a fishing boat. 1930 & 1931: Takes part in Fleetwood to Isle of Man Race, owned by R.S.Taylor (second place, 1931).

At some point in the 1930s 'Ploughboy' was owned by Bill Kitchen, and international speedway and TT racer. He kept the boat at Fleetwood.

1935 Takes part in Fleetwood to Isle of Man Race, owned by H.Foote. Other Crossfield yachts in the race are ‘Lalla Rookh' and ‘Nanette’.

1965: Bought by John Gill, housemaster at Rossall School, near Fleetwood. Her frames were found to be rotten. Mr Gill and his partner refastened the yacht completely and laminated 32 new oak frames and replaced several planks. A new deck was also fitted but the coach roof was left on, this being in perfect condition. ('Ploughboy' when built was not fitted with a cabin, so the coach roof would not be as old as the hull).

‘Ploughboy’ is used to teach sailing at the school. Sailed to Solway, Isle of Man, Menai Straits and Scottish Isles.

1978 sold to Brian Parry and taken to Gillingham, Kent

1996-2004 owned by Ian Ruffles, Gillingham

2004: Bought by Robert Raynor of Knott End on the other side of the Wyre Estuary from Fleetwood. Under his ownership ‘Ploughboy’ competed in Liverpool Nobby Races. He also sailed her up to Arnside, anchoring overnight at New Barns Bay.

2012: Bought by new owner. Kept at Gillingham in Kent. 2017: Advertised on Ebay for £14,500

2021: Change of ownership and undergoing restoration in Port Penryn, Wales.
boat.name: Ploughboy
boat.short_description: Ploughboy was built as a yacht for John Jackson of Walney Island as a replacement for Cock O'North which was wrecked on her maiden voyage. In 1960s and 70s she was owned by John Gill a house master at Rossall School south of Fleetwood and used to take pupils on sailing trips. She is now based in North Wales
